case_name: Legal representatives of Haji Ali Mohamed Haji Cassum v. State of Bombay

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 28 of 1950 from a judgment and decree of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay dated 19th March 1945 in Appeals Nos. 68 and 190 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal  Civil Appeal No. 28 of 1950  from a judgment and decree of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay dated 19th March, 1945, in Appeals Nos. 68 and 190 of 1942.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by MAHAJAN J. on February 5 1951.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. February 5. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by MAHAJAN J.--This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court of Judicature at. Bombay modifying the decree of the trial companyrt and decreeing partially the plaintiffs suit.

facts.text: The appellants are the legal representatives of the original plaintiff Haji Ali Mohamed Haji Cassum. The State of Bombay is the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by MAHAJAN J.--This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court of Judicature at. Bombay modifying the decree of the trial companyrt and decreeing partially the plaintiffs suit. The appellants are the legal representatives of the original plaintiff Haji Ali Mohamed Haji Cassum.

facts.text: Village Dahisar originally formed part of the Malad Estate comprising in all eight villages.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to this Controversy, briefly stated, are as follows -- Village Dahisar originally formed part of the Malad Estate companyprising in all eight villages.

facts.text: The said estate was conveyed by the East India Company to two Dady brothers for valuable consideration by a deed of indenture dated the 25th January 1819.

anchor.surface_text: The said estate was companyveyed by the East India Company to two Dady brothers for valuable companysideration by a deed of indenture dated the 25th January, 1819.

facts.text: By that conveyance all the lands in the eight villages were conveyed absolutely to the said purchasers and it was covenanted by the Company that the purchasers their heirs and assigns shall peaceably and quietly enjoy the said villages and receive and take the rents and profits thereof without any hindrance or interruption from the said Company.

anchor.surface_text: By that companyveyance all the lands in the eight villages were companyveyed absolutely to the said purchas- ers and it was companyenanted by the Company that the purchas- ers, their heirs and assigns shall peaceably and quietly enjoy the said villages and receive and take the rents and profits thereof without any hindrance or interruption from the said Company.

facts.text: By a sale deed dated the 13th December 1900 Haji Cassum father of the plaintiff purchased the village of Dahisar from its proprietors for a price of Rs. 130000.

anchor.surface_text: By a sale deed dated the 13th December, 1900, Haji Cassum, father of the plaintiff, purchased the village of Dahisar from its proprietors for a price of Rs. 1,30,000 and after his death the plaintiff became the pro- prietor thereof

facts.text: After his death the plaintiff became the proprietor thereof and as such received rents and assessment from the tenants and holders of the lands in the village according to the rights prevailing under the survey settlement which had taken place in the village about the year 1864-65.

anchor.surface_text: and after his death the plaintiff became the pro- prietor thereof and as such received rents and assessment from the tenants and holders of the lands in the village according to the rights prevailing under the survey settle- ment which had taken place in the village about the year 1864-65.

facts.text: In the year 1879 the Bombay Land Revenue Code was enacted.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1879 the Bombay Land Revenue Code was enact- ed.

facts.text: The draft rules were promulgated by a notification issued on the 5th June 1907.

anchor.surface_text: The draft rules were promulgated by a numberification issued on the 5th June, 1907.

facts.text: On the 25th July 1923 the plaintiff requested the Commissioner of Bombay Suburban District for a revision of the survey of Dahisar village.

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th July, 1923, the plaintiff requested the Commissioner of Bombay, Suburban District, for a revision of the survey of Dahisar village.

facts.text: The Commissioner by his letter dated the 14th March 1925 authorised the extension of the provisions of chapters 8 and 9 of the Land Revenue Code to the village in question.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner by his letter dated the 14th March, 1925, authorised the extension of the provisions of chapters 8 and 9 of the Land Revenue Code to the village in question.

facts.text: The revision was made by the Superintendent of the Land Records who submitted his report to the Commissioner on the 15th December 1926. This report was sanctioned by Government. The order sanctioning the revised survey was communicated to the plaintiff on the 23rd December 1927.

anchor.surface_text: The revision was made by the Superintendent of the Land Records who submitted his report to the Commissioner on the 15th December, 1926. This report was sanctioned by Government. The order sanctioning the revised survey was companymunicated to the plaintiff on the 23rd December, 1927.

facts.text: Under the revised survey the assessment of Rs. 4217 on the village lands was increased to Rs. 6057-3-2 and the plaintiff from that date started recovering the increased assessment from the tenants.

anchor.surface_text: Under the revised survey the assessment of Rs. 4,217 on the village lands was increased to Rs. 6,057-3-2, and the plaintiff from that date started recover- ing the increased assessment from the tenants of the lands in the village.

facts.text: At the time of the revision of the survey it was found that nine plots of land comprised in eleven field numbers which were formerly agricultural had been built upon and these were being used for non-agricultural purposes.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the revision of the survey it was found that nine plots of land companyprised in eleven field numbers which were formerly agricultural had been built upon and these were being used for number-agricultural purposes.

facts.text: On the 30th April 1934 he requested the Collector to assess non-agricultural assessment on these plots.

anchor.surface_text: On the BOth April, 1934, he requested the Collector to assess number-agricultural assessment on these plots.

facts.text: This request was refused by the Collector on the 17th July 1935.

anchor.surface_text: This request was refused by the Collector on the 17th July, 1935, in these terms--

facts.text: Against the order of the Collector the plaintiff appealed to the Commissioner. The Commissioner declined to interfere. This information was conveyed by the Collector to the counsel for the plaintiff on the 22nd May 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the Collector the plaintiff ap- pealed to the Commissioner. In his appeal he pointed out that certain additional lands in the village had been company- verted to number-agricultural uses subsequent to the revision of the survey in 1926. The Commissioner declined to inter- fere. This information was companyveyed by the Collector to the companynsel for the plaintiff on the 22nd May, 1937.

facts.text: On the 20th December 1937 he received a copy of the communication from Government to the Commissioner confirming the action of the Collector referencing Government Resolution No. s235/3a dated 8th March 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Against the Commissioners decision, the plaintiff appealed to the Governor in Council and on the 20th December, 1937, he received a companyy of the fol- lowing companymunication from Government to the Commissioner --

facts.text: Government Memorandum Revenue Department No. 5235-B/33 dated the 8th March 1937 confirmed the Collectors action in refusing the proprietors request for the levy of non-agricultural assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Government Memorandum, Revenue Department, No. 5235-B/33, dated the 8th March, 1937, companyfirmed the Collec- tors action in refusing the proprietors request for the levy of number-agricultural assessment.

facts.text: During the interval between 1927-37 a large number of plots of land mentioned in schedule II were put to non-agricultural uses by the tenants in possession of them and a number of buildings were constructed thereupon.

anchor.surface_text: During the interval between 1927-37 a large number of plots of land mentioned in schedule II were put to number- agricultural uses by the tenants in possession of them and a number of buildings were companystructed thereupon.

facts.text: The trial Judge negatived all the technical objections raised by the defendant and on the merits held that the Collectors action in refusing to levy non-agricultural assessment on the lands in question was wrongful. He granted the declaration prayed for but refused further relief.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge negatived all the technical objections raised by the defendant and on the merits held that the Collectors action in refusing to levy numberagricultural assessment on the lands in question was wrongful. He, there- fore, granted the declaration prayed for.

facts.text: High Court modified the decree granted declaration that plaintiff entitled to receive non-agricultural assessment on all lands used or to be used for non-agricultural purposes ordered levy on schedule I lands and consequential damages dismissed suit for schedule II lands.

anchor.surface_text: Two appeals were taken to the High Court against the decree of the trial Judge. That Court modified this decree and granted a declaration to the plaintiff that he was entitled to receive number-agricultural assessment on all lands which are and which may hereafter be used for number-agricul- tural purposes.

facts.text: Plaintiff made application for leave to appeal to the Privy Council on the 15th September 1945. During pendency plaintiff died and heirs impleaded. Certificate granted on the th February 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff being dissatisfied with this part of the decision made an application for leave to appeal to. the Privy Council on the 15th September, 1945. During the pendency of the application the plaintiff died and his heirs and executors were implead- ed as his legal representatives.

facts.text: There is no controversy in this appeal as regards the reliefs that have been given to the plaintiff by the High Court. The appeal concerns the further relief refused to the plaintiff in respect to the lands mentioned in schedule II.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy in this appeal as regards the reliefs that have been given to the plaintiff by the High Court. The appeal companycerns the fur- ther relief refused to the plaintiff in respect to the lands mentioned in schedule II.

Section 48 of the Code is in these terms -- 48.  1  The land revenue leviable on any land under the provisions of this Act shall be assessed, or shall be deemed to have been assessed, as the case may be, with reference to the use of the land--  a  for the purpose of agriculture,  b  for the purpose of building, and  c  for a purpose other than agriculture or building.

concepts.interpretation: Assessment fixed under the Act is liable to be altered if land use changes, notwithstanding the fixed term, by authority per rules prescribed by Provincial Government.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: essed, as the case may be, with reference to the use of the land--  a  for the purpose of agriculture,  b  for the purpose of building, and  c  for a

concepts.unlisted_description: Provides for assessment of land revenue based on use (agriculture, building, other) and alteration upon change of use.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act came into force, the Government drafted rules under the provisions of section 214 for promulgation.

Rule 92 is one of the rules promulgated under the provisions of the Act and it runs thus - When land assessed for purposes of agriculture only is subsequently used for any purpose unconnected with agricul- ture the assessment upon the land so used shall, unless otherwise directed by Government, be altered under sub-

concepts.unlisted_description: Mandates Collector to alter agricultural assessment to non-agricultural upon change of use, unless Government directs otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: This refusal was in contra- vention of the provisions of rule 92 which imposes on the Collector a duty to make alteration in the assessment, unless he has been directed to the contrary by Government.

concepts.interpretation: Imposes mandatory duty on Collector to alter assessment unless directed otherwise by Government.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the order of the Collector the plaintiff ap-

concepts.unlisted_description: Mandates Collector to alter agricultural assessment to non-agricultural upon change of use, unless Government directs otherwise.

concepts.interpretation: Rule is imperative; Collector has no option and must alter assessment upon application unless Government has previously directed otherwise in clear terms.
concepts.unlisted_description: Mandates Collector to alter agricultural assessment to non-agricultural upon change of use, unless Government directs otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: He executed an agreement under the provisions of section 216 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code and made a formal application in that behalf as required by the Code and the rules made thereunder.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions for agreement for revision of survey.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner by his letter dated the 14th March, 1925, authorised the extension of the provisions of chapters 8 and 9 of the Land Revenue Code to the village in question.

concepts.unlisted_label: Chapters 8 and 9 Bombay Land Revenue Code
concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions extended to village for survey revision.

after service of notice under section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure, instituted the present suit,
It was contended that it was barred under section 4  c  of the Revenue Jurisdiction Act and under article 14 of the Indian Limitation Act.

on those lands and his action was ultra vires. Relief was given to the plaintiff regarding those lands as prayed for.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ompanycerns the fur- ther relief refused to the plaintiff in respect to the lands mentioned in schedule II. It was companytended on behalf of the appe

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the Government was bound to use its power to levy assessment as trustee for the transferee and that the exercise of this power could not be arbitrarily refused by it.

concepts.interpretation: Appellant contention that Government acts as trustee for proprietor in levying assessment; court does not adopt.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: that the section merely provided that the persons in possession of land were liable for such assessment but it did number say that it was obligato- r

concepts.unlisted_description: Government bound as trustee to exercise assessment powers for benefit of landowner.

concepts.interpretation: Court rejects: liability imposed by statute cannot be defeated by discretion or rules negativing it (obiter).
concepts.unlisted_label: Section 48(2) and Rule 92 Bombay Land Revenue Code
concepts.unlisted_description: Effect of provisions on obligation to levy altered assessment.

anchor.surface_text: We think that when a liability is imposed by a statute, that liability cannot be defeated by the exercise of any discretion by Government or by making rules which may negative that liability,

concepts.interpretation: Statutory liability prevails over governmental discretion or rules that negate it.
concepts.unlisted_description: Liability created by statute cannot be nullified by executive discretion.

issues.text: Whether the suit is barred under section 4(c) of the Revenue Jurisdiction Act and under article 14 of the Indian Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that it was barred under section 4  c  of the Revenue Jurisdiction Act and under article 14 of the Indian Limitation Act. On the merits it was pleaded that the action of the survey officer

issues.text: Whether the action of the survey officer and the Collector in refusing to levy non-agricultural assessment on lands contained in the two schedules was lawful and proper, and whether the civil court could question the discretion of the Government in such matters

anchor.surface_text: On the merits it was pleaded that the action of the survey officer and the Collector in refusing to levy non-agricultural assessment on lands contained in the two schedules was lawful and proper and that the civil court could not question the discretion of the Government in such matters. The trial Judge negatived all the technical objections

issues.text: Whether the survey officer erroneously declined to make non-agricultural assessment on lands converted before the 1926 survey and whether his action was ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: As regards the former, it was held that the survey officer had erroneously declined to make non-agricultural assessment on those lands and his action was ultra vires. Relief was given to the plaintiff regarding those lands as prayed for.

issues.text: Whether for lands converted to non-agricultural use after the 1926 survey, it was within the discretion of the Government to refuse alteration of assessment such that the discretion could not be questioned in a court of law

anchor.surface_text: As regards the latter, it was held that it was within the discretion of the Government to order an alteration of the assessment on such lands and this discretion could not be questioned in a court of law. The plaintiff being dissatisfied with this part of the decision

issues.text: Whether confirmation by the Government of the Collector's refusal to alter assessment amounts to a direction by Government otherwise under rule 92
Whether rule 92 in imperative terms directs the Collector to alter assessment on agricultural lands converted to non-agricultural use, with no option unless directed otherwise by Government
Whether under the 1819 conveyance, Government covenants, trustee role, and 1907 resolution, the Government was bound to levy assessment and could not refuse or direct contrary to rule 92

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that under the terms of the conveyance dated 25th January, 1819, and of the covenants contained therein it was not open to the Government or the Collector to refuse the alteration of the assessment claimed by the plaintiff... It was said that the Government was bound to use its power to levy assessment as trustee for the transferee

issues.text: Whether the true effect of section 48(2) and rule 92 is that Government is not bound to levy altered non-agricultural assessment but has discretion, and whether court can interfere

anchor.surface_text: On the merits it was pleaded that the action of the survey officer and the Collector in refusing to levy non-agricultural assessment on lands contained in the two schedules was lawful and proper and that the civil court could not question the discretion

arguments.claim: Under the terms of the conveyance dated 25th January 1819 and covenants therein Government or Collector not open to refuse alteration of assessment claimed and Government could not give direction under rule 92 contrary to covenants and assurances.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that under the terms of the conveyance dated 25th January, 1819, and of the covenants contained therein it was not open to the Government or the Collector to refuse the alteration of the assessment claimed by the plaintiff and that the Government could not give any direction under rule 92 which would be contrary to these covenants and assur-

arguments.claim: Government bound to use power to levy assessment as trustee for transferee and exercise could not be arbitrarily refused.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the Government was bound to use its power to levy assessment as trustee for the transferee and that the exercise of this power could not be arbitrarily refused by it.

arguments.claim: Government Resolution dated 5th June 1907 indicated rules under Land Revenue Code not intended to affect adversely owners of alienated lands and Collector bound to make assessment as required by plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the Government Resolution dated 5th June, 1907, clearly indicated that the rules framed under the Land Revenue Code were not intended to affect adversely the owners of alienated lands and the Collector was bound to make an assessment as required by the plaintiff.

arguments.claim: Government never exercised power under rule 92 never gave direction to Collector contrary mere affirmation of erroneous order of Collector does not amount to direction contemplated by rule 92.
arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmation of Collectors action does not amount to direction; power must be exercised in clear unambiguous terms notified properly; conceded no such decision taken

arguments.claim: Collectors refusal contravened rule 92 which imposes duty to alter assessment unless directed contrary by Government.

anchor.surface_text: This refusal was in contra- vention of the provisions of rule 92 which imposes on the Collector a duty to make alteration in the assessment, unless he has been directed to the contrary by Government.

arguments.claim: Rule 92 in imperative terms directs Collector to alter assessment when agricultural lands converted to non-agricultural use; Collector has no option must proceed upon application.
Confirmation by Government of Collectors action does not amount to direction contrary under rule 92; such power must be exercised in clear unambiguous terms and notified.

True effect of section 48(2) and rule 92 is Government not bound to levy altered assessment on non-agricultural lands; section makes possessors liable but not obligatory on Government; court no jurisdiction to interfere with discretion.
arguments.court_reasoning: When a liability is imposed by a statute that liability cannot be defeated by exercise of discretion by Government or rules negativing it

arguments.claim: For lands converted post-1926 it was within discretion of Government to order alteration of assessment and this discretion could not be questioned in court of law.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the latter, it was held that it was within the discretion of the Government to order an alteration of the assessment on such lands and this discretion could not be questioned in a court of law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumed confirmation was direction but disagree; no clear direction given under rule 92

arguments.claim: Survey officer erroneously declined non-agricultural assessment on pre-1926 lands and action ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the former, it was held that the survey officer had erroneously declined to make non-agricultural assessment on those lands and his action was ultra vires.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: icate for leave to appeal to the Privy Council was granted on the th February, 1947, and the appeal preferred under the certificate is number before u

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court granted declaration levy on schedule I lands

holdings.text: Rule 92 in imperative terms directs the Collector to alter the assessment when agricultural lands are converted to non-agricultural use; the Collector has no option and must proceed upon application unless otherwise directed by Government.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of rule 92 imposes mandatory duty on Collector; language is imperative with exception only for Government direction.

holdings.text: The confirmation by Government of the Collector's refusal does not amount to a 'direction otherwise' under rule 92.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere affirmation of Collector's erroneous order does not constitute exercise of power under rule 92; no resolution or notification issued.

holdings.text: Government's power under rule 92 to direct otherwise must be exercised in clear and unambiguous terms, notified properly as it affects civil rights.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Power affecting civil rights requires explicit exercise and public notification; conceded no such decision or direction existed.

holdings.text: High Court's refusal of relief to plaintiff for lands in schedule II (post-1926 conversions) is reversed; plaintiff entitled to direction for levy of non-agricultural assessment on those lands and payment to him.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Collector contravened rule 92 without valid Government direction; civil court can enforce mandatory statutory duty.

holdings.text: Collector's refusal to levy non-agricultural assessment contravened rule 92, imposing duty to alter unless directed otherwise by Government.

anchor.surface_text: This refusal was in contra- vention of the provisions of rule 92 which imposes on the Collector a duty to make alteration in the assessment, unless he has been directed to the contrary by Government. It was not denied that by the 17th July, 1935, no such direct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of rule 92 to facts; no prior Government direction existed at time of refusal.

holdings.text: When a liability is imposed by statute, it cannot be defeated by Government discretion or rules negativing it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory mandate prevails over discretion; however, not necessary to decide as case resolved on other grounds.
